Award.AwardTitle: Mating regulates stem cell division frequency in testes of Drosophila melanogaster
Award.AbstractNarration:
The question how adult stem cells maintain themselves and how they produce specialized cells to replenish tissues is fairly well understood for several model tissues. However, how the activity of stem cells is regulated within the adult is only poorly understood. Specifically, whether stem cells can increase the production of specialized cells in situations of demand has not been addressed in any model organism yet.

In male fruitflies, each germline stem cell division ultimately leads to the development of exactly 64 mature gametes. Preliminary studies show that demand for more gametes, induced by mating experiments, leads to a response: an increase in the frequency at which male germ line stem cells divide. The investigator plans to use genetic and molecular techniques for identifying the communication pathway regulating the response. It is expected that the studies reveal which tissues are involved in the communication, which biochemical molecules mediate the communication, and which target genes are activated within the germ line stem cells in reponse to demand. The outcome of the proposed research will have broad impacts on our understanding how environmental events utilize biochemical pathways to feed back on stem cells and thereby on the vitality and activity of specific tissues in the adult body.

The proposed research has a strong teaching and outreach component. Fruitflies are an excellent model organims widely used in research and education. Graduate students, undergraduate students, high school students, and K-12 teachers participating in the proposed research will be trained both intellectually and technically. The investigator has trained many female and minority students and intends to continue recruiting students from programs supporting students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mating regulates germ line stem cell division frequency in testes of Drosophila melanogaster. 

Many highly differentiated, but short-lived cells, such as blood, skin, and sperm cells, need to be constantly reproduced from stem cells. It appears reasonable that stem cells have to adjust to the demand for differentiated cells. For example, skin stem cells have to produce more skin cells to adjust to the growth of the individual during childhood than they have to produce to maintain the skin in the adult. In females, blood stem cells have to produce more blood cells during the reproductive cycles of the individual than during childhood and menopause. Yet, no mechanisms has been identified that explains how stem cells sense and respond to the demand for specialized cells. 

 

Intellectual Merit:The gonad of Drosophila melanogaster is an excellent model to identify and study these mechanims.The laboratory discovered that Drosophila males have a reduced sperm count and an increased germline stem cells (GSCs) mitotic activity upon multiple rounds of mating with virgin females. Using tools, such as expression studies, loss-of-function analysis, and tissue- and cell-specific knockdowns, the researchers showed that the increase in GSC activity is dependent on the activity of several G-protein coupled receptors(GPCRs) within the GSCs. GPCRs are proteins found on the surface of cells from almost every species. When these GPCRs recognize a specific chemicals (ligand) they release a chain response within the cells that can can open channels on the cells, modify the salt concentrations within the cells, and/or cause specific gene products to become produced. Most of the knowledge on GPCRs comes from their role within the mammalian nervous system, where they become activated by neuro-transmitters, such as Serotonin, Octopamine, or Dopamine, and play a role in the transmission of an electrical pulse along the nerves. The proposed role of GPCRs in cell divisions is novel and opens many new questions in the field of stem cell biology and cancer research. The researchers also identified several other proteins that are required for the increase in GSC divisions, and showed that specific gene products become indeed produced at higher levels in mated males. The authors have submitted manuscripts for publication to communicate their findings to the research community and the public. They also presented their findings on national and international meetings.  

 

Broader Impact:The proposed studies contributed to several areas of fundamental interest in biology, including cell signaling, transcriptional regulation, and evolution. Furthermore, they allowed to develop an interaction with an expert in genomics research and with a protein chemist.

The proposed project resulted in many professional training opportunities. During the funding period, three graduate and 11 undergraduate students were personally trained by the PI. The PI also hosted two K-12 teachers from the NSF-sponsored GIFT program and five high school students from the UGA Young Dawgs Program who worked in the laboratory. About 50% of the trained students were female. Furthermore, the PI hosted six middle school interns, toured middle school students through the lab, and collaborated with one of her K12-teachers in teaching a genetic sclass at Hillsboro middle school, a school mostly visited by students from underrepresented groups.
